question: Question_05_(a)
statement:
A study conducted at a waste disposal site reveals soil contamination
over a region that can be described as the interior of the circle

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
x^2+y^2 = 16\end{align*}

where \emph{x} and \emph{y} are in miles. In order to build a circular
enclosure to contain all polluted territory, the manager of the site
wants to find the radius of the smallest circle centered at \emph{(2,
2)} that contains the entire contamination region. Formulate this as a
constrained optimization problem, clearly stating the objective function
and the constraint. Note that you do not need to do any computation in
part (a).
sols:
Examine the picture below

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{Math105Q5a2013.jpg}
\caption{Math105Q5a2013.jpg}
\end{figure}

The red circle describes the contaminated region. Our blue circle has to
be just large enough to completely contain the red circle. Hence, we
need to find the distance between any point on the red circle and the
centre of the blue circle, \emph{(2,2)}. The radius of the blue circle
is then the smallest number that is bigger than all these distances.

The distance between any point \emph{(x,y)} and \emph{(2,2)} is given by
$\displaystyle \sqrt{(x-2)^{2} + (y-2)^{2}}$. Hence, the radius \emph{r} we are looking
for is the maximum value of distances from points on the red circle to
the centre of the blue circle:

$\displaystyle r = \sqrt{(x-2)^{2} + (y-2)^{2}}$

subject to this point $(x,y)$ lying on the red circle

$\displaystyle x^{2} +y^{2} = 16$

Maximizing this distance gives the smallest possible radius such that
the blue circle still encloses the entire contamination area.
hints:
We with to make the radius of the new circle around \emph{(2,2)} as
small as possible and as large as necessary to contain all points from
the first circle around \emph{(0,0)}.

Given any point \emph{(x,y)}, what is the distance from that point to
the centre of our new cirle \emph{(2,2)}?
